Award.AwardTitle: TWC: Small: Understanding and Mitigating the Security Hazards of Mobile Fragmentation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Mobile computing technologies are rapidly evolving and phone (and other mobile device) manufacturers are under constant pressure to offer new product models. Each manufacturer customizes operating system software for its devices and often changes this software to support its new models. Given the many manufacturers in the mobile device marketplace and the many different generations of products, there are many customized branches of mobile operating systems in use at any time. Unfortunately, high-impact, security-critical flaws have been introduced through the combination of the operating system customization process and the design of mobile applications. This project is the first to systematically study and mitigate such security hazards. The researchers are collaborating closely with device manufacturers to transfer the results of the project into practice.

More specifically, the project involves an in-depth study of the security risks and pitfalls that lead to fragmentation-related vulnerabilities. The researchers are developing novel technologies to detect such flaws in existing systems and avoid them when building new ones. The project includes the development of automatic analysis techniques that scan a large number of factory images to identify inconsistencies in the protection of a system capability on different operating system (OS) layers (e.g., Android framework layer, Linux layer, etc.), and across a customized version and its official counterpart. This consistency check helps elevate the security qualities of customized systems to that of Android official systems. Furthermore, to mitigate the security risk introduced by the services or apps designed for cross-version, cross-device compatibility, the research team is studying techniques for automatically analyzing a variety of services on new OS releases, enhancing the mechanism for capturing exploits on them, and eliminating new security hazards like hanging capabilities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project aims at understanding the security and privacy implications of mobile fragmentation, including the security risks introduced by customizations of mobile systems, applications and services, and interactions between them and their components across less protected common interfaces when integrating these systems/applications/services. The research further contributed to the development of innovative technologies to detect and mitigate such risks, and protect various mobile, IoT systems.

Intellectual Merit. In the project, we systematically analyzed the security impacts of fragmentation on different aspects of mobile computing, including operating systems (OS), application libraries, URL schemes and mobile services. On the OS level, our research shows that hanging attribute references left in the OS components due to customization of the same OS to different devices (phone, tablet, etc.) can be utilized to invoke unintended apps, leading to privilege escalation. Similar security hazards can also be introduced through a Time of Check to Time of Use risk fundamentally caused by the competition among different app stores on the same device. Even on better protected OS X, the interfaces between OS and diverse applications, including keychain and sandbox, turns out to be inadequately guarded and expose sensitive user information such as password. Inside individual apps, libraries are extensively customized, not only over the same OS, but across both Android and iOS. Such customizations are found to be related to the spread of both vulnerable and malicious code, even across platforms. Further customized URL schemes for cross-app invocation are shown in our study to disclose such a significant attack surface that a remote adversary becomes capable of infecting multiple apps on the same device through their Webview instances using a malicious site, to orchestrate a coordinated, multi-stage attack. On the mobile service level, our study revealed that attempts to integrate multiple mobile payment services are highly error-prone, opening avenues to circumventing the security protection put in place by payment service providers.

Not only have such systematic security analyses led to high-impact discoveries, which resulted in the changes to the designs and implementations of popular systems, such as Apple’s keychain, but they also brought in an array of innovations for mitigating the security hazards of mobile fragmentation. Examples include Harehunter for automated detection of hanging references, HareGuard to capture the attempts to exploit the vulnerabilities, ViewFinder that utilizes a URL-guided fuzzer for finding weaknesses causing the cross-Webview infections, the semantic-based fuzzer that can discover the vulnerabilities on the interfaces between different system, application components and an NLP-based document analyzer for detecting the logic flaws in fragmented mobile service integration.  Also the project demonstrated that fragmentation can be leveraged to enhance the protection of mobile systems.  As examples, by linking customized mobile libraries together, malicious apps that passed the vetting of Apple App Store were captured using the Android apps carrying similar libraries; the traffic produced by apps running on different OS versions was found to be useful for fingerprinting them, enabling effective app monitoring and malware detection.  The project has resulted in 13 papers, most published on most competitive security venues. Also the findings reported have impacted the protection of popular systems (Android and iOS) and high-profile applications (Facebook, Twitter and others).

Broader Impacts. The outcomes of this project have been extensively disseminated through presentations at leading security venues and numerous invited visits around the world. Also, the project involved HBCU students through summer interns, who have received research training on mobile security.
